column1: King of Prussia (also referred to as KOP) is a census-designated place in Upper Merion Township
column2: Montgomery County
column4: United States. As of the 2010 census
column6: 936. The community took its name in the 18th century from a local tavern named the King of Prussia Inn
column7: which was named after King Frederick the Great of Prussia. Like the rest of Montgomery County
column8: King of Prussia continues to experience rapid development. One of the largest shopping malls in the United States
column10: is located here. Also located here is the headquarters of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission Region I. King of Prussia is considered to be an edge city of Philadelphia
column11: consisting of large amounts of retail and office space situated at the convergence of four highways.

column1: == History ==
The eponymous King of Prussia Inn was originally constructed as a cottage in 1719 by the Welsh Quakers William and Janet Rees
column2: founders of Reesville. The cottage was converted to an inn in 1769 and did a steady business in colonial times as it was approximately a day's travel by horse from Philadelphia. Settlers headed west to Ohio would sleep at the inn on their first night on the road. In 1774 the Rees family hired James Berry to manage the inn
column3: which henceforth became known as "Berry's Tavern". General George Washington first visited the tavern on Thanksgiving Day in 1777 while the Continental Army was encamped at Whitemarsh; a few weeks later Washington and the army bivouacked at nearby Valley Forge.

column1: Parker's spy map
column2: created by William Parker
column5: but a local petition in 1786 identified it as the "King of Prussia". It was possibly renamed in honor of Benjamin Franklin's pro-American satirical essay "An Edict by the King of Prussia". At some point a wooden signboard of the inn depicted King Frederick II (Frederick the Great) of Prussia. The inn is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.The inn was forced to move with the expansion of U.S. Route 202. U.S. 202 is a major north-south highway that passes through the town from southwest to northeast. Its construction as a modern expressway would have caused the destruction of the King of Prussia Inn; however
column6: historic preservationists managed to prevail upon the state of Pennsylvania to avoid this important structure by building north and southbound lanes on either side of it. For more than a quarter century the inn was marooned on a median island
column7: with motor traffic whizzing past on both sides. It was sealed up for years
column8: surrounded by a high fence. The inn was successfully relocated in 2000 and opened to the public in October 2002.

column1: The extensive suburban development that has taken place since the 1960s in King of Prussia has led urban planning scholars like Joel Garreau to label the area as an epitome of the edge city phenomenon
column2: a situation where the most vibrant economic growth and prosperity in a metropolitan area (in this case
column3: Philadelphia) no longer occurs in the urban center
column4: but rather at its periphery. Before 1960
column5: the Greater King of Prussia area was known for little more than being the place of Washington's winter respite in 1777-8 (see Valley Forge National Historical Park). The growth in King of Prussia developed around the convergence of four highways with the construction of the King of Prussia mall
column7: and housing developments.Daniel Berrigan and his brother Philip Berrigan began their Plowshares Movement at the General Electric Weapons Plant in King of Prussia in 1980. That event and the subsequent court proceedings surrounding the 'Plowshares Eight' were dramatically depicted by Emile de Antonio in the 1983 motion picture In the King of Prussia.In the late 1980s
column8: developer Dennis Maloomian acquired a golf course near the King of Prussia mall and planned a mixed-use residential and retail development that would include a town center for King of Prussia. The proposed development needed to be rezoned but Upper Merion Township officials and local residents were opposed to the plans. After several court battles
column9: the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled in Maloomian's favor in 2003. The planned development became known as the Village at Valley Forge and would include a suburban downtown
column12: and offices. The retail area would be known as the King of Prussia Town Center. The first part of the town center was completed in 2014 with the opening of a Wegmans grocery store. This was followed by the construction of the downtown area with several stores and restaurants. Offices are being constructed and residential areas are in development.By the 2000s
column13: the business park in King of Prussia was outdated and was losing tenants. By 2009
column14: several office building owners pushed for Upper Merion Township to improve the business park. Improvements were made to King of Prussia including landscaping the median of US 202
column15: installing King of Prussia signs at the borders to the community
column16: creating a shuttle service connecting the business park to nearby train stations
column17: and changing the zoning laws to allow for apartments and townhouses to be constructed in the business park. The vacancy rates at the business park have since dropped.In 2016
column18: the two sections of the King of Prussia mall
column20: were joined to create one large shopping mall after an expansion corridor was built.

column1: == Geography ==
There is no incorporated city of King of Prussia
column2: although the United States Postal Service office there has carried that name since 1837. Its ZIP code is 19406. King of Prussia's boundaries
column3: as defined by the Census Bureau
column4: are the Schuylkill River to the north
column7: and I-76 to the south. However
column8: the Greater King of Prussia Area is often cited to include Bridgeport
column9: parts of Wayne and Radnor Township
column11: as well as most of Gulph Mills.  The local fire department carries the King of Prussia name
column12: whereas the police department and the school district carry the Upper Merion name. King of Prussia is located 20 miles (32 km) northwest of Philadelphia.

column1: == Climate ==
The climate in this area is characterized by hot
column2: humid summers and generally mild to cool winters. According to the KÃ¶ppen Climate Classification system
column3: King of Prussia has a humid subtropical climate

column1: == Economy ==
King of Prussia has an unemployment rate of 4.30% and an annual job growth of about 1.44% and 38% over the next ten years.  A large portion of that comes from the King of Prussia mall
column2: the largest shopping complex in the United States by shopping area square footage and the numerous employers in the area. The King of Prussia mall consists of over 400 stores
column4: and 8 anchor stores. The mall attracts 22 million visitors annually and produces $1.1 billion in annual sales. A large business park is located to the northwest of the King of Prussia mall
column5: with over 60 commercial and industrial companies on 676 acres. There are about 60
column6: 000 people employed in King of Prussia
column7: which is three times the resident population.King of Prussia is home to the headquarters of Nuclear Regulatory Commission Region I
column8: which oversees 25 nuclear power reactors at 16 nuclear power plants in the Northeastern United States.According to Upper Merion Township's 2010 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report

column1: In addition
column2: major commercial property owners in King of Prussia formed an organization in 2010 called the King of Prussia District (KOP-BID) that works to improve the physical environment
column5: tax and transportation policies that will keep King of Prussia competitive in the region.

column1: == Sports ==
The  Philadelphia Freedoms tennis team of World TeamTennis played in King of Prussia in 2008 and 2009. Whenever a tennis event was to occur
column2: a temporary tennis stadium that seated 3
column3: 000 was constructed in the parking lot of the King of Prussia mall.  Eventually
column4: the Freedoms left for The Pavilion at Villanova University in 2010.

column1: == Education ==
=== Schools ===
Public school students in the King of Prussia area attend schools in the Upper Merion Area School District. The district is served by five elementary schools: Bridgeport
column2: Caley
column4: Gulph and Roberts. All students in the Upper Merion Area School District also attend Upper Merion Area Middle School and Upper Merion Area High School.

column1: King of Prussia also has a Private school
column2: Mother Teresa Regional Catholic School. It formed in 2012 by the merger of Mother of Divine Providence in King of Prussia and St. Teresa of Avila in West Norriton.

column1: === Colleges ===
The Penn State Great Valley campus was once located in King of Prussia from 1963 to 1974 before relocating to Great Valley.  In 1982
column2: the college opened up a new facility called Penn State King of Prussia Center.

column1: == Points of interest ==
King of Prussia is home to the King of Prussia mall
column2: which is the largest mall in the United States in terms of leasable space. The mall consists of over 400 stores
column4: and over 40 restaurants. The mall has several luxury stores that have their only Philadelphia area location in King of Prussia. The King of Prussia mall is surrounded by several big-box stores
column8: including a United Artists Theatres and an iFLY indoor skydiving center.  The King of Prussia Town Center is a lifestyle center that consists of Wegmans
column10: and a downtown area with dining
column12: and service establishments and a Town Square. The town center is part of the Village at Valley Forge
column13: a 122-acre mixed-use development under construction that consists of retail
column18: and the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia's "Specialty Care and Surgery Center".King of Prussia is also the location of the Valley Forge Casino Resort
column27: and a seasonal poolside club called Valley Beach. Valley Forge National Historical Park
column28: which consists of the site where General George Washington and the Continental Army made their encampment at Valley Forge during the winter of 1777-78 in the American Revolutionary War
column29: is located to the west of King of Prussia.King of Prussia is home to the King of Prussia Volunteer Fire Company 9/11 Memorial honoring the lives lost in the September 11 attacks. The memorial
column30: which was dedicated by the King of Prussia Volunteer Fire Company on the 10th anniversary of the attacks in 2011
column31: consists of two steel beams recovered from Ground Zero at the World Trade Center in New York City. The 9/11 Memorial is located adjacent to the King of Prussia Volunteer Fire Company station on Allendale Road across from the King of Prussia mall.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Transportation ===
King of Prussia has retained its role as an important crossroads throughout United States history. In addition to the Inn
column2: from the earliest days
column3: the intersection supported two general stores. Today
column4: four major highways meet in or near the center of King of Prussia. The Schuylkill Expressway (I-76)
column7: ends in King of Prussia at the Pennsylvania Turnpike
column8: an east-west toll road across the southern portion of the state that heads west towards Harrisburg as part of I-76 and east around the northern suburbs of Philadelphia towards New Jersey as I-276. The US 422 freeway begins at US 202 near the center of town and heads northwest to Pottstown and Reading; thanks to reconstruction in 2000
column9: motorists can now travel directly from Reading to Philadelphia without passing onto US 202. US 202 is the only major highway that becomes a surface road through the area
column10: heading southwest towards West Chester as a freeway and northeast towards Norristown as Dekalb Pike
column11: a surface road. Important local roads in King of Prussia include PA 23
column12: which runs through King of Prussia between Valley Forge and Bridgeport along Valley Forge Road; Gulph Road
column13: which runs from PA 23 near Valley Forge National Historical Park and heads southeast to junctions with I-76 and US 202 near the King of Prussia mall before leading to Gulph Mills; and Henderson Road
column14: a north-south road through King of Prussia that intersects PA 23 and US 202 before ending at Gulph Road near an interchange with I-76.Pennsylvania Department of Transportation District 6
column20: is headquartered in King of Prussia.

column1: King of Prussia is well served by SEPTA Suburban Division bus routes 92
column6: and 139 at the King of Prussia Transit Center at the King of Prussia mall
column7: with the routes providing service to West Chester
column8: the Exton Transportation Center at the Exton Square Mall
column16: SEPTA Suburban Division bus route 95 runs from Gulph Mills to the Willow Grove Park Mall in Willow Grove. The Gulph Mills station is served by SEPTA's Norristown High Speed Line
column17: which runs between the 69th Street Transportation Center and the Norristown Transportation Center. There is a proposed rail link to King of Prussia serving as a spur of the Norristown High Speed Line that is estimated to add $946 million in assessed property values for about a $1 billion investment.King of Prussia is also served by theconnector shuttle bus
column18: which connects the King of Prussia business parks with SEPTA Regional Rail's Manayunk/Norristown Line at Norristown Transportation Center and SEPTA Regional Rail's Paoli/Thorndale Line at Wayne station during peak weekday hours. The KOP-BID operates theconnector shuttle buses. The Greater Valley Forge Transportation Management Association operates The Rambler as a community shuttle around the King of Prussia area Monday through Saturday
column24: and the Upper Merion Township Municipal Building. Taxicab and limousine service in King of Prussia is provided by three companies. Carpooling is available in King of Prussia
column25: with the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission offering a service that can match commuters with transit services
column28: and walking and bicycling options.OurBus provides intercity bus service from King of Prussia to Park Avenue in the Manhattan section in New York City as part of a route running from Lancaster to New York City. The bus stop in King of Prussia is located at the King of Prussia Park and Ride
column29: a park and ride lot on King of Prussia Road. The route started on December 21
column30: 2017. Greyhound Lines also has a bus stop at the King of Prussia Park and Ride.King of Prussia is 18 miles (29 km) from 30th Street Station in Philadelphia
column31: which has intercity rail service provided by Amtrak
column32: and 26 miles (42 km) from Philadelphia International Airport
column33: which has flights to domestic and international destinations.Norfolk Southern Railway operates freight trains through King of Prussia along the Harrisburg Line that follows the Schuylkill River and the Dale Secondary that follows US 202 and the Pennsylvania Turnpike. The Abrams Yard operated by Norfolk Southern Railway is located in King of Prussia on the Harrisburg Line.There are several trails for hiking and bicycles that serve the King of Prussia area
column34: some of which are under development. Valley Forge National Historical Park has a network of trails that total over 20 miles (32 km)
column35: including the Joseph Plumb Martin Trail and the Chapel Trail. The Schuylkill River Trail connects Valley Forge National Historical Park via Sullivan's Bridge across the Schuylkill River to the Manayunk section of Philadelphia
column37: the Schuylkill River Trail will follow the river between Pottsville and Philadelphia for a total length of about 130 miles (210 km). A section of the Chester Valley Trail passes through King of Prussia; when complete
column38: the trail will run 22 miles (35 km) between Norristown
column39: where it will connect to the Schuylkill River Trail

column1: === Utilities ===
Electricity and natural gas in King of Prussia is provided by PECO Energy Company
column2: a subsidiary of Exelon. Water in the King of Prussia area is provided by Aqua Pennsylvania
column5: a subsidiary of American Water. The Upper Merion Township Public Works Department provides wastewater service to King of Prussia. Trash and recycling collection in King of Prussia is provided by private haulers.

column1: === Health care ===
Einstein Healthcare Network operates an outpatient healthcare facility in King of Prussia. The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia's 135
column2: 000-square-foot (13
column3: 000 m2) "Specialty Care and Surgery Center" opened in King of Prussia in 2015.  The Gulph Road facilities includes practices in sports medicine
column5: and pediatric imagery.  The facility is part of a larger site known the Village at Valley Forge.
